newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan predatory exports to rouse tensions - Gingrich.
newsitem.headline: Japan predatory exports to rouse tensions - Gingrich.

text.p: For Japan to seek economic growth through predatory export policies and a restricted domestic market would inflame trade tensions, U.S. House Speaker Newt Gingrich said on Tuesday.

Gingrich told a news conference in Tokyo that trade remained an "irritant" in the U.S.-Japan relationship and that important differences remained in such areas as the automotive sector, telecoms, paper, agriculture and photo film.
"Although our trade deficit with Japan had been declining, it has begun to increase substantially," Gingrich said.

"Understandably, Japan wants to boost economic growth. In an economy led by export industries, driving up exports becomes a simple answer. However, seeking stronger growth through predatory export policies and a restricted domestic market will not only fail to re-invigorate Japan's economy. It will also inflame trade tensions between our two countries," he said.

Gingrich also said it would be "equally disastrous to pursue a demand-led recovery through a lax monetary or fiscal policy," which he said U.S. experience had shown led to rising deficits and rampant inflation.
"The way to gain broader economic growth in both our countries is through a deeper commitment to economic freedom and deregulation," he said.
Gingrich added that deregulation would spur Japan's economy and increase market access, leading to "a more equitable balance of trade between our two countries".
